column1: Kui Buri (Thai: กุยบุรี
column2: pronounced [kūj būrīː]) is a district (amphoe) in the northern part of Prachuap Khiri Khan Province

column1: Mueang Kui was an ancient city of the Ayutthaya Kingdom. In the reign of King Boromakot
column2: Kui was fourth-class city. In the Rattanakosin era
column3: King Rama II established a Mueang Bang Nang Rom
column4: which had its city hall in Kui Buri. King Mongkut (Rama IV) renamed Mueang Bang Nang Rom "Prachuap Khiri Khan"
column5: with the same city hall. When King Chulalongkorn created Monthon Phetchaburi
column6: Kui Buri was included. In 1898 the city hall was moved to Ko Lak bay and Kui Buri was downgraded to a subdistrict of Mueang Prachuap Khiri Khan District. The minor district (king amphoe) of Kui Buri was re-established on 19 July 1960 and officially upgraded to a full district on 16 July 1963.

column1: The British diplomat John Crawfurd visited the area in 1822 during the mission described in his book Journal of an embassy from the Governor-General of India to the courts of Siam and Cochin-China: exhibiting a view of the actual state of those kingdoms. He reported the name of the town as "Kwi".
Neighboring districts are Sam Roi Yot to the north and Mueang Prachuap Khiri Khan to the south. To the west is the Tanintharyi Division of Myanmar
column2: to the east the Gulf of Thailand.

column1: The main river of the district is the Khlong Kui.
The district is divided into six sub-districts (tambons)
column2: which are further subdivided into 47 villages (mubans). There are two townships (thesaban tambons) in the district. Kui Buri covers parts of tambons Kui Buri and Kui Nuea
column3: and Rai Mai covers parts of tambon Sam Krathai.
